data.text: Breaking News: Sam Bankman-Fried, the FTX founder, was denied bail by a judge in the Bahamas after he was arrested on charges of fraud. https://t.co/bb06aRv2gT

Donald Trump’s family business lost a criminal contempt trial that was held in secret last fall, according to a newly unsealed court document and people with knowledge of the matter. The company was fined $4,000 after failing to turn over documents. https://t.co/IYIUg57OCs

The German prince accused of organizing a plot to overthrow the German government met at least once with Russian diplomats at a consulate in Germany, according to two people familiar with the investigation into the conspiracy. https://t.co/Ayu1FfwqSH
Critics Notebook: Why does the news about a fusion breakthrough feel vaguely familiar? Blame our favorite sci-fi movies and comic books. https://t.co/wQplcecZJy

From @TheAthleticFC: Croatia's manager Zlatko Dalic has suggested a first-half penalty given to Argentina was “very cheap” after his side was defeated 3-0 in the #FIFAWorldCup semifinal. https://t.co/Rw7o7pX2IX
In this article, you can search among the many metro areas across the nation to explore the climate impact of your neighborhood. https://t.co/qCEgqqYpPa

But density isn’t the only thing that matters. Wealth does, too. Rich households on Manhattan’s Upper East Side have a bigger climate impact than their neighbors just a few blocks away because they fly more, have bigger apartments and buy more stuff. https://t.co/qCEgqqYXEI https://t.co/M09ppv6K8V

But in more distant suburbs and exurbs, average emissions per household can be two to three times as high, with some of the largest climate footprints in the nation. https://t.co/qCEgqqYpPa https://t.co/0T9RFthqYA

New York is a prime example of this pattern. The densest and most transit-friendly neighborhoods near the city center run deep green, with some of the lowest emissions per household nationwide. https://t.co/qCEgqqYpPa https://t.co/Cm4JHpPD51

Households in denser neighborhoods close to city centers tend to produce fewer greenhouse gases, on average, than those in the suburbs and exurbs. These residents typically drive less and live in smaller spaces that use less energy to heat and cool. https://t.co/qCEgqqYpPa https://t.co/K5qOTJe67M

We love your tips. We guard our sources. We adore documents. Facts can change the world. Here's a quick guide. You can name any NYT reporter, including me, in the tip, and it will have safe passage. Thank you. https://t.co/yTQaHdLr4G
Thank you for reading the original story (w/@jo_becker) and for all your reactions and tips. https://t.co/g7iNpvOW57

For SCOTUS to justify its extraordinary independence, it needs to maintain the public trust, said Louis Virelli, a law professor.

“When the public feels the justices aren’t doing their part, the cost for the justices will be more transparency," he said.
But calls for new transparency rules-- the kind that might prevent the secret efforts at influence we reported-- are growing.
Legal scholars say it's not so simple: the Supreme Court's independence is part of its design, and enforcement is tough, because it *is* the highest authority.
Lawmakers are calling for further investigation and asking a basic question: why aren't SCOTUS justices bound by the same rules as other federal judges?

But in talking with hundreds of workers over many months, we found a problem with these arguments: the supposedly precise systems just are not accurate. https://t.co/7vSfdOGU8c

The most fascinating part of this reporting? Talking to the (many) believers. They say this is inevitable– everything is measured now. That industrious workers should be rewarded, derelict ones fired. They cite workers who cheat: say, by taking two remote jobs at once.

Pauses can lead to lost pay and jobs. Some companies have figured out how to pay workers only for the minutes when they are “active.” 

It’s gotten to the point where workers are buying devices that jiggle their computer mice. (One model is called The Liberty.) https://t.co/G6QxjfXqtQ

Don’t underestimate the scale. Our reporting shows that 8 of the 10 largest U.S. employers track productivity metrics for ind'l workers, many in real time. 

Docs, engineers, podcast producers + many others are being measured too. Social workers are dinged for “idle time.” https://t.co/NLvp3frzDf

New: Meet Rev. Richardson, a hospice chaplain who had to rack up “productivity points” as she tended to the dying.

Her story illustrates the rise of the worker productivity score, one of the biggest expansions of employer power in generations. 🧵 https://t.co/mfoigUk56t https://t.co/OMl7Xh41F6

Just published: The Rise of the Worker Productivity Score.

This is across incomes and industries. Pauses can lead to penalties, from lost pay to lost jobs.

But in many cases, the measurements aren’t even right. 

Our investigation: https://t.co/mfoigUk56t

My own advice in this moment is to be cautious about sweeping assessments of the state of Metoo. After many years of reporting, I can tell you: we just don’t know what’s going to stick.
This matters way beyond Weinstein. It goes to the question: as #Metoo built momentum– and however the winds of social attitudes shift– what ultimately gets enshrined in the law?

But the judges poked and prodded at the conviction and… found it sound. In doing so, they 
effectively expanded how sex crimes prosecutions can be conducted in New York.

Last winter, an appellate panel bore down HARD on Weinstein’s conviction. This wasn't the patriarchy reasserting itself! The judges were all female + appeared ultra-skeptical. The legal world whispered: the female judges don't buy it. Weinstein’s gonna be reversed.
But often very important to showing a pattern of sexual misconduct. (Those kinds of witnesses are also expected to play key roles in Weinstein's upcoming LA trial.)

The judge permitted a chorus of additional victims to buttress those allegations. That’s a controversial move in NY courts, because of the longstanding principle that defendants shouldn’t be subject to pile-on accusations.

Despite the overwhelming number of allegations against him, the Weinstein case/conviction pushed boundaries. The women were not so-called “perfect” victims. (They’d had consensual sex and friendly contact.)

Yesterday, amid concern about the future of #Metoo, a NY appeals court affirmed Harvey Weinstein’s conviction. A foregone conclusion, right? No! This was high drama and a big deal for the future of #Metoo (🧵) https://t.co/L1bzmSCwUK
